title: Before 1 July 2016, will South Korea announce that the Terminal High-Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) missile defense system will be deployed on the Korean Peninsula?
preds:
The latest:  China and Russia, as of June 29, continue to "urge the United States to back off, saying THAAD's deployment could also affect their security." China's Xi urges caution over U.S. missile deployment in South Korea
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-southkorea-security-idUSKCN0ZF12J Russia categorically opposes plans to deploy US THAAD missile defense systems in South Korea since this will pose direct threat to the country's security, Russian Ambassador to South Korea Alexander Timonin told Sputnik.
http://sputniknews.com/military/20160630/1042209421/thaad-russia-korea.html South Korea considering possible locations for U.S. THAAD deployment.  Candidate locations include existing U.S. military bases.
http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2016/06/06/South-Korea-considering-possible-locations-for-US-THAAD-deployment/2221465232851/ NOTE:  Very possible it will happen before the end of the year, but definitely not before July 1.
Roll-out of this system is going to require an official announcement, and would then take several days (or weeks). It cannot be deployed by tomorrow.

https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/271143 as pointed out by @Anneinak, " the military would make a final decision on the deployment of the U.S.-made advanced anti-missile system by the end of this year." Seems safe to forecast a zero chance of an announcement by tomorrow.

http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=3020651&cloc=joongangdaily%7Chome%7Cnewslist2 South Korean Defense Minister Han Min-koo told lawmakers Tuesday that the military would make a final decision on the deployment of the U.S.-made advanced anti-missile system by the end of this year.

COMMENT:  Key words:  ". . .by the end of this year".  Not tomorrow!

- United States and South Korea have begun talks on THAAD (29 June 2016).
- However, little more than 24 hours until "before 1 July" expires so likelihood question will be answered affirmatively is virtually nil.

Very probable that THAAD will be deployed, perhaps even over the coming months. It seems very unlikely that it is going to be deployed in the next couple of days, however, not least because finer points of the agreement that will facilitate this have yet to be worked out.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-southkorea-security-idUSKCN0ZF12J This will likely happen, but not in the next couple of days.  I hope.

Most likely this won't happen before July 1, but here's the latest: WASHINGTON HOPES TO WRAP UP ANTI-MISSILE DEAL WITH SOUTH KOREA
"The United States wants to wrap up discussions with South Korea on the deployment of a sophisticated defense system, the Pentagon said Friday, two days after North Korea’s latest missile tests.
Seoul and Washington have for weeks been in talks about deploying the advanced US THAAD missile system in South Korea to protect against the potential threat from Pyongyang—a move vehemently opposed by China.  
He said discussions had “progressed well,” but there were still “some details to work out.”  North Korea tested two Musudan medium-range missiles just hours apart on Wednesday (June 22).  The first was seen as a failure, but leader Kim Jong-Un hailed the second as a complete success.
http://www.japantoday.com/category/world/view/washington-hopes-to-wrap-up-anti-missile-deal-with-south-korea THAAD SEEN AS CAPABLE OF INTERCEPTING N. KOREA MID-RANGE MISSILE

"The advanced U.S. missile defense system THAAD is believed to be capable of intercepting North Korea's intermediate-range ballistic missiles if it is deployed in South Korea, Seoul's defense chief said Friday.  On Wednesday, the North fired off what is believed to be two Musudan mid-range missiles, marking its fifth and sixth launches since April."

Clips from Nation article:
“We can’t deny that (North Korea’s) technological development is making progress, and the situation is alarming,” Japanese government spokesman Koichi Hagiuda told reporters.
The North has publicly displayed an ICBM, called the KN-08, which uses the same engine technology as the Musudan but has never been test-fired.
Jeffrey Lewis, director of the East Asia Nonproliferation Program at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies in California, said the international community had to find a way to get Pyongyang to accept a missile test moratorium.
“If we do nothing, this ends in a successful flight test of the Musudan-based KN-08,” Lewis said." The Diplomat, June 23, 'North Korea's Musudan Missile Test Actually Succeeded. What Now?': http://thediplomat.com/2016/06/north-koreas-musudan-missile-test-actually-succeeded-what-now/
Clips from Diplomat article:
"It’s far from obvious where Pyongyang goes from here. Kim Jong-un’s statement on Thursday suggests that the signaling value of the Musudan tests has been accomplished and, with a limited inventory of missiles remaining, Pyongyang may choose to hold off on further testing. Conversely, it could continue testing to protest international isolation and sanctions. The nightmare scenario is the possibility of Pyongyang using the know-how its gained with its Musudan testing to eventually conduct a flight test its KN-08 ICBM, with a possible atmospheric nuclear detonation to remove any doubts about miniaturization.
However, amid attempts at an uneasy rapprochement with Beijing and even a willingness to enter a track 1.5 dialogue with regional and U.S. diplomats this week, Pyongyang may choose to tamp down its spate of testing somewhat and claim that its long-sought goal of credibly being able to threaten Guam with a nuclear strike has been achieved. With the country under economic stress from sanctions and under increased agricultural stress precipitating a famine, Kim has plenty of reason to turn his attention to the economic leg of byungjin." 38th North, June 23, 'A Partial Success for the Musudan': http://38north.org/2016/06/jschilling062316/
Clips from 38th North article:
"So we should probably assume they don’t really care, that this was about propaganda and image rather than engineering and weapons development. They have achieved something that is as close to a win as possible without overflying Japan, and if they try again there’s a good chance that Musudan #7 will be an embarrassing failure just like Musudan #5.
Best case, they declare victory and go home, and make a quiet note to never actually trust the Musudan in wartime. Worst case, they tell their engineers to go back to their ground test facilities and turn this one-shot stunt into a useful weapon. The engineers in question would probably be quite happy to know they still have jobs, and turning the results from this spurt of unreasonably fast testing into a reliable weapon, would occupy them for a year or two at least. If they come back a year from now, testing Musudan missiles one at a time and with three to six months between tests, then we can start worrying about an operational Musudan." Comments: Five days left....... ironic that Kim Jong Un will be the ultimate factor of WHEN this system is deployed..... what side of the bed he gets up from, a fight with his wife, lukewarm Guk for lunch, stubbed toe, an attack of piles.... 'The Secretary and the Ministers condemned in the strongest terms North Korea's recent provocative actions, including its fourth nuclear test and multiple ballistic missile launches as clear violations of United Nations Security Council resolutions. The Secretary and the Ministers affirmed the intention of the three countries to cooperate closely with one another and with the international community, to enforce United Nations Security Council resolution 2270. The three officials urged North Korea to refrain immediately from taking further actions that aggravate tensions and called on North Korea instead to focus on fulfilling its international obligations and commitments."
"The Ministers and the Secretary praised the close trilateral communication and cooperation that took place at various levels before and immediately following these incidents. "The Ministers and the Secretary discussed the upcoming trilateral missile warning exercise, PACIFIC DRAGON, which is to be conducted in accordance with the Trilateral Information Sharing Arrangement (TISA). With the continued missile failures, some pressure for THAAD introduction has been lifted. My guess is that behind the scenes there is a delicate balance between exercising the THAAD deployment and waiting to see if China is carrying through on economic sanctions against DPRK. The backdrop to all this is the complexity of the South China Sea challenges. Obama has generally shown a tendency to try to compartmentalize issues that are naturally intertwined. If China fails to live up to its sanction commitments, then there is less reason to hold off on THAAD. It also could be that the US is simply trying to dial down the overall temperature of the US_China relations, knowing that  the UN Arbitration ruling is coming shortly and the chance of a military casualty is rising.  The more I think about the China questions, the more complex it becomes.

Clips from article:
"South Korea, U.S. and Japan have held joint search and rescue drills numerous times in the past, but this marks the first time we hold a missile warning exercise,” a high-ranking official of Seoul’s Defense Ministry told The Korea Herald. “The drill is confined to the framework of the trilateral information sharing pact (on Pyongyang’s nuclear and missile capabilities) and is not a strategic exercise.”
“One Aegis-level vessel from each country,” will participate in the drill a South Korean defense official told CNN, which will involve “detecting and tracing a hypothetical North Korean missile.” However, it will not involve the interception of the missile. (A military fighter jet will stand in for the missile.)
The exercise will focus on acquiring and sharing intelligence between the three countries “because of the limitations of the information-sharing pact,” a South Korean defense official said. South Korea, Japan and the United States signed an intelligence-gathering pact in 2014 to respond to North Korea’s growing missile threat.
“To hold such drills has been decided to better defend South Korea from ever-increasing nuclear and missile threats from North Korea and detailed plans have been worked out,” the South Korean defense official said. However, the South Korean defense ministry emphasized that the drill will have ”nothing to do with any country’s missile defense program.”

That says to me that the dates will be similar to 2014, when it began on June 26th, the last Thu in June. I don't think there is any chance that they will announce THAAD before the military exercises end, and I think it is very likely they will take at least a week before announcing anything, if not longer. I think the exercises are partly about testing a THAAD system that may already be clandestinely installed, and they will want to make sure everything is hunky dory, AND then still need the right political moment, before announcing. So I think that means they miss the July 1 date with near certainty, but that THAAD is very likely coming.

SEOUL, Feb. 16 (Xinhua) -- "Chinese Vice Foreign Minister Zhang Yesui on Tuesday expressed opposition to South Korea's plan to deploy a sophisticated U.S. missile defense system after a meeting here with his South Korean counterpart" SEOUL, Feb. 16 (Xinhua) -- Chinese Vice Foreign Minister Zhang Yesui on Tuesday expressed opposition to South Korea's plan to deploy a sophisticated U.S. missile defense system after a meeting here with his South Korean counterpart. Zhang met in Seoul with South Korean First Vice Foreign Minister Lim Sung-nam to co-chair the seventh China-S. Korea high-level strategic dialogue between foreign ministries. The senior-level dialogue came after South Korea and the United States agreed to begin talks about deploying the Terminal High-Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) in the South Korean territory in response to the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK)'s nuclear and missile threats. Pyongyang launched a long-range rocket, which some see as a test of banned ballistic missile technology, on Feb. 7 following its fourth nuclear test on Jan. 6. Zhang told reporters after the meeting in Seoul that he exchanged views with Lim about the THAAD issue, among other issues, and said China expressed oppositions to the THAAD deployment. Zhang said China attaches great importance to ties with South Korea, and is ready to work along with the country to boost the sound development of bilateral relations, noting that China is firmly committed to the denuclearization of the Korean peninsula, which conforms to the common interests of China and South Korea. China opposes the DPRK's nuclear test and rocket launch, and supports a new and effective resolution at the UN Security Council, but sanctions are not an end in themselves, and a fundamental solution to the issue should be sought through dialogue and negotiations, Zhang said. The senior Chinese diplomat urged relevant parties to act prudently, in an apparent reference to Seoul and Washington that have agreed to launch talks about the THAAD deployment. China hopes relevant parties would show respect for China's interests and act with prudence, as the deployment is not conducive to easing the current tension and maintaining peace and stability in the region, but would impair China's strategic security interest, Zhang said. The THAAD, designed to track and destroy ballistic missiles at an altitude of 40 km to 150 km, has been put under suspicion about its operational effectiveness in South Korea as hundreds of shorter-range DPRK missiles can fly at a much lower altitude. There are also safety concerns as the THAAD X-band radar emits super-strong microwaves, allegedly harmful to human bodies within 3.6 km while paralyzing electronic devices and airplanes within 5.5 km. South Korean officials said the two sides had "candid, in-depth, and constructive" discussions on bilateral ties and the security conditions on the peninsula. South Korea attaches great importance to ties with China and is ready to work for their further development, and would maintain consultations and communications with China regarding the THAAD deployment issue, said the S.Korean officials. Related: China, S. Korea hold strategic dialogue on Korean Peninsula nuclear issue SEOUL, Feb. 16 (Xinhua) -- The foreign affairs ministries of China and the Republic of Korea (ROK) held a strategic dialogue here Tuesday to discuss issues including the Korean Peninsula nuclear problem. By David Brunnstrom
WASHINGTON (Reuters) – China needs to understand that it is a matter of life or death for South Koreans to protect themselves from possible North Korean nuclear attack and that Beijing should engage in talks over the possible deployment of a new U.S. anti-missile system there, a senior South Korean official said on Monday.  The United States and South Korea earlier began talks on possible deployment of the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) system after North Korea tested its fourth nuclear bomb on Jan. 6 and launched a long-range rocket on Feb. 7, but China firmly opposes the move.  Shin Beomchul, director-general for policy planning at South Korea’s foreign ministry, told a seminar that more conversations were need with China on the issue.  “I hope to ask China’s understanding of what (South) Korea is feeling about the North Korean threat,” he told the Center for Strategic and International Studies.  “It is not the usual threat, it is a nuclear threat. That’s very serious. We are now in the live-or-die situation,” he said.
“We have to solve the … misunderstanding, but the fundamental point is that to protect our country is the top priority.”
Ultimately, the way to resolve the controversy would be to decrease the North Korean threat, he added. Mark Lambert, director of the Office of Korean Affairs at the U.S. State Department, told the seminar Beijing was still refusing a U.S. offer of briefings to explain that the system was not aimed at limiting China’s defense capabilities.
South Korean Deputy Foreign Minister Kim Hyoung-zhin stressed the need for all countries to put pressure on North Korea to abandon its nuclear program through full implementation of international and bilateral sanctions.
He said North Korean leader Kim Jong Un’s government did not look likely to give up nuclear weapons under any circumstances, but did respond to external stimuli.  “If these elements are tightly interwoven without any loophole … the Kim Jong Un regime will realize that it cannot survive unless it gives up its nuclear program and takes steps towards denuclearization,” he said.  Lambert said U.S. experts wanted to explain that the THAAD system would not negate China’s nuclear deterrent as its radars would be pointed northeast into North Korea, not into China.  “We need to have that dialogue. But unfortunately to date, officials in Beijing have been unwilling to meet with our officials and hear that.” http://newsdaily.com/2016/04/china-must-see-missile-defense-is-live-or-die-for-south-korea-seoul-official/

I know precisely zero about military things, which is why I chose this question. Turned out to be hard & took about 2 hours. I started by googling what a THAAD is and what is going on that would make this a reasonable question. Apparently a THAAD is a missile you can shoot at other missiles to knock them down. Useful if you have people shooting missiles at you. South Korea wants THAADs because North Korea has recently shown, via tests, that (1) it can make big bombs, and (2) it can shoot them really far. (It tested a hydrogen bomb and it launched a satellite.) OK, next was a question about BASE RATE: how long do negotiations  usually take before the nation announces it's going to install THAADs? Here I had to constantly remind myself what the question actually was not "will South Korea have THAADs in place by 1 July 2016" (which seemed impossibly soon for something so logistically complicated) but merely "will they announce that they will deploy it". Getting a base rate was very hard because (1) almost no deals of this kind have ever been done, only the UAE and Oman as far as I can tell; (2) the news almost always reports only when a deal is reached, not when talks begin. The only thing I could find was a Feb 2009 announcement [1] that the UAE "may reach agreement to buy THAAD in 18 months", and a Dec 2011 announcement [2] that they did --- so ~2 years between news of talks starting, and news of deal closed. I found a May 2013 "deal closed" announcement for Oman but no "talks began" announcement. OK, that's not a lot of data but let's move on. When did the South Korea talks begin? Officially, on 4 March 2016 [4]. That's less than 4 months to the deadline in the question, or six times faster than the UAE case. That would seem to make a YES answer very unlikely. Let's estimate. In [1] a deal is estimated to take 18 months but in reality took 4 months longer. Let's say 18 months is average time and 4 months is one standard deviation. That would mean a deal in 4 months is 3.5 standard deviations below average. Wildly improbable event, 0.03% chance under normal distribution. If we call 4 half a standard deviation we get a 4% chance. Let's settle on 2% for now. In order to adjust it we may ask (1) if talks had really been going on in secret since much earlier, or  (2) if the UAE example is a bad guide to the SK example. On (1) I found that indeed SK has been eyeing THAADs for a while [5], since 2013. But not exclusively, it considered also other missile defense systems, e.g. sold by Israel. By mid 2014 it had apparently decided to not buy from anyone but develop its own [6], which was estimated to take 5-7 years. That makes me think the deal really is starting now; the fact that North Korea made its bombs known in 29 Jan 2016 reinforces it. THAAD talks scheduled for barely a month later doesn't seem like coincidence. So (1) does not change my 2% estimate. On (2) I am less confident. According to Wikipedia, SK and UAE are about equally strong allies of the United States [7,8]. In both cases there was resistance to THAAD deployment from neighbors (Arab countries in UAE case, China in SK case). If anything I'd guess that Chinese resistance is a bigger hurdle than resistance from any Arab country, so I'd expect SK deals to take even longer than UAE deals. There's also the issue of popular opinion; in SK politicians have to care if Koreans don't want the American presence (there have been protests), while in the UAE the king pretty much just does whatever he wants. Another point towards expecting SK deals to take more than 2 years. On the other hand, perhaps there is some notion of urgency in the SK case, since there is a neighbor with demonstrated WMD capability. I forget what the situation was around the UAE in 2011 but to this day no Arab country has nukes. This kind of makes me want to raise it to 5% or so. Finally, there is a chance that this whole THAAD business is just meant to pressure China into pressuring North Korea; soon after THAAD negotiations began, China voted for sanctions against NK in the UN Security Council. As far as I can tell, there were THAAD meetings in March just before the UNSC meeting, and none since then. I will revise the probability down to 2% again. [1] http://www.defenseworld.net/news/2821/UAE-may-buy--7-billion-advanced-missile-defence-system-from-Lockheed-Martin
[2] http://www.lockheedmartin.com/us/news/press-releases/2011/december/1230-thaad-uae.html
[3] http://www.armyrecognition.com/may_2013_news_defence_army_military_industry_uk/sultanate_of_oman_to_buy_the_air_defense_missile_system_thaad_from_united_states_2705134.html
[4] http://thediplomat.com/2016/03/its-official-us-south-korea-begin-talks-on-thaad/
[5] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terminal_High_Altitude_Area_Defense#International_users
[6] http://english.sina.com/world/2014/0602/705974.html
[7] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Korea%E2%80%93United_States_relations
[8] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates%E2%80%93United_States_relations

My 20min reading of Korean politics throws up umpteen reasons this wont happen and only one reason it might just happen by July.
The Korean government lost the majority in the parliament on Wednesday. That means two weeks just talking about the implications of the election. Then weeks of setting out positions all the 1st tier priorities that the election threw up, which are mostly economic. President Park would be hopelessly out of touch to start making foreign policy announcements when the country is completely focused on other issues.  A scheduled meeting for deputy foreign ministers of Korea, Japan and the US will meet in Seul next week to talk DPRK. They wont be making big announcements (these announcements don't come from deputy FM level meetings anyway) - they'll be working out the implications of the election for their strategic objectives and the 'comfort women issue'. Then they discuss the meeting with their respective capitals...  There's only two ways I can think of that this is announced by July.  First, the DPRK forces action with some sort of missile test or similar. Second, President Park determines she's a lame duck and looks for things she can announce that don't need parliamentary approval (ie: executive orders, to use the US nomenclature).  But even there, I don't think she'd want to put this topic on the table right now when she doesn't know how the new government will respond.  In my view, there is just too much going on in Korean domestic politics for this to really be announcable in 6 weeks. And there's no scheduled moment that I'm aware of that would make it a natural event. So why is the market at 59%? I think the market is over-estimating the chances of this happening because so many people ignore the time frame. Many comments seem to see the recent remarks from a US defence official (I forget name and rank and no time to look it up) that, "it will happen" as being definitive. But "it will happen" is exactly the sort of forecast that GJP scorns - no time frame, no specific details of what "it" entails etc. Just a vague and a-temporal certainty. 
The market has been steadily drifting up from a very low base over the last 6 days, which I think matches that announcement pretty well. I suspect over-reaction to one piece of evidence. 
I've also noticed a tendency for many participants to offer 0% or 100% predictions. I suspect a number of extreme forecasts are dragging up the average.  I'm comfortable forecasting slightly above last week's average. That wasn't an initial consideration, but now I'm thinking of it and think it's appropriate. While time is ticking down (6 weeks now rather than 7 then) *something* has moved the average forecast a long way. There's a chance my explanation is wrong, and it outweighs the impact of losing 14% of the time available for resolution. We will know much more next week after the deputy FM meeting in Seul. THAAD is complementary to Patriot in a layered ballistic missile defense system. The Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) system is a long-range, land-based theater defense weapon that acts as the upper tier of a basic 2-tiered defense against ballistic missiles. It’s designed to intercept missiles during late mid-course or final stage flight, flying at high altitudes within and even outside the atmosphere. This allows it to provide broad area coverage against threats to critical assets such as population centers and industrial resources as well as military forces, hence its previous “theater (of operations) high altitude area defense” designation. This capability makes THAAD different from a Patriot PAC-3 or the future MEADS system, which are point defense options with limited range that are designed to hit a missile or warhead just before impact. The SM-3 Standard missile is a far better comparison, and land-based SM-3 programs will make it a direct THAAD competitor. So far, both programs remain underway. https://www.defenseindustrydaily.com/thaad-reach-out-and-touch-ballistic-missiles-updated-02924/

Neither China nor Russia want THAAD deployed in the region. If it's not a bright-red line, then at least it is sunlit. Both Russia and China see THAAD as a step to decrease their missile capabilities (regardless of THAAD's original design). But both Russia and China recognize the chaos and threat DPRK is creating for western countries as well as themselves. Hence, the recent UN Security Council sanctions.  From the US and its allies side, an essential question has to be ....how serious is China and Russia at punishing DPRK and how much effort will they provide to bring DPRK into line. If the sanctions are mostly words, then US and allies will likely take the step forward to THAAD deployment. This would almost certainly be true if another DPRK ballistic nuclear test was implemented. This is of course a guess, but it seems that US and allies will continue the talks with South Korea and Japan about the technical implementation planning. They will make noise about it. But, the deployment will be held off at this point. The trigger will be another DPRK test or the apparent weakness of sanction enforcement by China and Russia.
